about.title: Prof. Mark Eidelman, MD
about.intro: Prof. Mark Eidelman is a world-renowned pediatric orthopedic surgeon with over 40 years of experience, specializing in complex limb deformity corrections and reconstruction. He currently serves as the Director of the Pediatric Orthopedics Unit at the Rambam Health Care Campus in Haifa, Israel, and is a Clinical Assistant Professor at the Technion Faculty of Medicine.

expertise.title: Pioneering Expertise
expertise.text: Prof. Eidelman is internationally recognized for his groundbreaking work in the field of pediatric orthopedics. A significant career highlight includes being the first physician to introduce the revolutionary Taylor Spatial Frame technique in Israel in 2003, dramatically advancing the treatment of complex limb lengthening and deformity correction for children.

academic.title: Academic Contributions & Global Impact
academic.paragraph_1: Dedicated to both clinical care and academic advancement, Prof. Eidelman has authored over 100 scientific publications in peer-reviewed journals, contributing significantly to the global understanding and treatment protocols for pediatric orthopedic conditions.
academic.paragraph_2: His commitment to patient care extends globally, exemplified by his participation in international medical delegations, where he performs marathon surgeries to treat children in areas with limited access to specialized medical expertise.

recovery_time.question: How long is recovery?
recovery_time.answer: Total recovery is approximately 12 months, with most patients returning to normal activities by month 6-8.

risks.question: What are the risks?
risks.answer: Complication rate is <2% with proper care. Common concerns are addressed during consultation.

fly.question: Can I fly after surgery?
fly.answer: Flying is typically allowed 2-3 weeks after surgery with proper precautions. We provide detailed travel guidelines.

max_gain.question: What's the maximum gain?
max_gain.answer: Most patients achieve 5-8cm safely. The exact amount depends on individual bone tolerance.
